comments.text:
@Slambear  
Hey, love the content as always – and I totally understand the need for sponsorships! Just a gentle note though: Opera has been under majority Chinese ownership for a while now. For those of us concerned about data privacy or national security, that might be worth keeping in mind. No hate, just thought it was worth mentioning!

Just to add some context: European cybersecurity agencies like Germany's BSI and ENISA have specific guidelines and minimum standards for browser security. It's worth noting that Opera may not fully meet these standards, especially concerning data processing and ownership transparency. For users in sensitive environments, this might be an important consideration.

# supply-chain-attack
#State-Influenced Software Compromise
#"Software Supply Chain Compromise by State Actors"
# State-Backed Software Tampering
#"Nation-State Software Backdooring"
#"State-Enabled Supply Chain Attacks"
#"Malicious Code Injection by Hostile Governments"

I truly appreciate the content you create, and I don’t mean to undermine the sponsorship in any way. I understand that Hardware Unboxed is primarily focused on gamers and hardware enthusiasts, and I enjoy that content. However, as technology evolves, the overlap between hardware and IT security becomes increasingly important, and I think it’s valuable for the community to stay informed on these broader implications.

comments.text:
For Canada only Bestbuy sells FE cards and rarily, Canada Computers and Memory Express have the most reasonable 9070XT prices and CC had the most stock typically, and the everything else you pretty much ignore until prices stabilize.

The 9070XT should be 850, but in reality that was only the first few days with the rebate.

After that, its never been under 950, but 950 cards are availible fairly regularly.

The 5070ti here is regularly availible at MSRP of 1090 Canadian.

I think a lot of gamers just fail to realize that for even AMD and especially NVidia, companies have a market (enterprise/AI) who will pay 5x more for the same die space, so in a time where fab space is limited, they aren't going to make us a priority.

Then, after people have "gotten  used to" the new prices, they'll never go back down significantly because unlioe other markets, there aren't enough players for competition to work well enough in that realm.

Our best hopes to avoid further increases and get slight relief, is AI demand finally being saturated such that supply exists for gaming cards. Unlikely to happen anytime soon though.

comments.text:
All cards are overpriced everywhere. How close some cards current market prices are to their MSRPs does not really matter. We all buy on a specific budget with maybe some wiggle room. 
For instance, for my budget (in the EU) I am more prone to compare 9070XT with a 5070 rather than a 5070ti, where the XT is a better value. 
Regardless, I would steer anyone buying a GPU for anything but high fps 4K RT gaming (so for instance high fps 1440p gaming with some light RT and FG) to look for a deal on a 5070 non ti or a 9070 non XT (depending on your use-case and feature needs). 
Or even better, finding a great deal on a used last gen GPU like a 7900XT or 4070ti super.
If you already have a GPU like that or better, just keep playing and enjoy ignoring the completely unwelcoming current GPU market. Don't give AMD nor nVidia a grand for incremental upgrades, in some cases even sidegrades.

comments.text:
Where I live, the 5070ti is 940 euro and the 9070xt is 784. I am buying it in installments, but the difference for me in performance is not worth it enough. When am I going to enable PT? 9070xt performs too bad in Black Myth Wukong for it to be a natural situation. Other than that, Alan Wake 2 is insanely unoptimized (864p on console in performance mode). For the games I want to play, like Doom The Dark Ages, I will be able to push it to 4k native at 40-50 fps and then turn on a cheeky fsr quality upscale with some frame gen if I feel like it to max out my mini led's tv refresh rate. Expedition 33 again nearly 60 fps MAXED out graphics at 4k native, I will use the upscaler swapper software to swap XeSS for FSR4 for easy nice upscaling to 60 fps and having it look amazing. If I want to turn on PT, I will go to FSR balanced or performance and see if it works. 

Its the first time in 7 years ever since my old potato gave up and swapped to console that I have come back to the pc scene and I am building a pc. It feels good. I hate having developers locking settings behind their quality or performance toggles and on top of that the crossplay situation is just not good enough.
comments.author: @sungjin-woo3894

comments.text:
I think part of the issue is that Nvidia got such a bad rep with rtx 50 and all the driver issues that AMD became the "premium" brand.
FSR4 is amazing and with the help of Optiscaler, you can use it on almost any game. So the DLSS advantage is basically gone.
RT is now totally usable on AMD. Sure Nvidia is still better, but not a difference of "I can enable it" vs "No way in hell I can use it".
By the way, I have a 9070XT and I can run PT at 60fps on a ultrawide 1440p monitor on CP2077, but I feel there's more ghosting with PT due to more being raytraced, so I run at RT phsyco.

Also, the gap between the 9070 and the XT grew because that's what they manage to sell at.
That $50 price gap that AMD gave was super stupid and a re-run of the 7900XT vs XTX

comments.text: $599 was a price that was always stupidly too low. Who the hell told them to charge such a ridiculous price? There is absolutely no way they could have ever produced enough cards to supply the demand at that price. The price should have been in the $699-729 range. Even worse for AMD, the price was so low that, even selling everything they could make, their GPU sales would down 16% from last year. Now, you're starting to see 9070XT for as low as $737, and that's a far more reasonable price than $599. I compared the minimum prices I could find on modern cards. For the 5060Ti, 5070, and 5070Ti, the minimum price is about 10% over MSRP, which is about right, since the dollar is down 10%. For the 9070XT and 9070 they are about 23% over the MSRP, which tells you that the MSRP was about 13% too low; thus, the MSRP should never have been below $689.

comments.text:
Very interesting. Just for fun I looked at the local prices in one Swedish web store. There the cheapest RX 9070 XT in stock was priced 8990 SEK and the cheapest RTX 5070 Ti in stock was listed at 12290 SEK. If I counted this correctly that 9070 XT is 26.85% cheaper than the RX 9070 XT. Now the prices are including VAT which is 25% in Sweden. So dropping VAT and converting to USD they are $739.5 FOR THE 9070 XT and $1011 for the RTX 5070 Ti.

So it seems that compared to the US we are just a hair better off regarding the 9070 XT but worse when off when looking at the RTX 5070 Ti.

Now if I look at the cheapest listed, disregarding if it's in stock nothing really changes for the RX 9070 XT but the cheapest RTX 5070 Ti with only one in stock is listed at 10579SEK. Drop VAT and that's 8463SEK, and exchange rates makes that $870. This a bit closer to the US prices.

Looking back this is rather uncommon situation here in Sweden. From what I can remember from years past the AMD based cards has been more expensive than the Nvidia based cards they competed with here. Back when the RTX 2070 Super was released I was looking at buying a RX 5700 XT. I had registered on a list waiting for one to be available but after about two months I saw a RTX 2070 Super being sold for less than the cheapest RX 5700 listed and I just canceled my registration and had that card in my hand the day after.

AMD graphics cards has been rather slow to appear on the market here in Sweden and often overpriced compared to in other countries.

comments.text:
This video is one of the most pointless ones I have seen in a LONG time lmao. 

1. NVIDIA announced 10-15% price increases across ALL products and regions recently, (maybe even today? or yesterday?) the prices in this video will NOT hold
2. The main reason you are seeing lower NVIDIA pricing is because 50 series is NOT selling. Most retailers around the globe are selling 3-4 Radeons for every Geforce card, and this is due to many factors: Supply issues, Driver issues, defect issues, underwhelming and disappointing uplift in performance from 40 series, all of which ARE NVIDIA's fault and they have done nothing about.
3. EVERYONE and I mean EVERYONE knew the 9070 series pricing wouldn't last. Its been in the tech news about the re-bates, this is not a surprise and is NOT new information 
4. Biggest reason RDNA4 pricing is so up in the air is SUPPLY & DEMAND. They had more supply than NVIDIA and already sold it, this rolls into my point above where AMD is actually selling compared to 'Fail-Well'. The demand is continuing, forcing companies to rush more supply and causing price hikes while supply is under such heavy demand. Its not rocket science. I think HUB is just blind to when AMD is doing something right, which is not new and why I largely stopped watching. 

Here's the thing: HUB and anyone else acting like a Radeon GPU needs to be 'better price for the same performance' in order to even be worthy of consideration, is flat out wrong. AMD IS at feature parity when it comes to your average PC gamer, you only need NVIDIA for CUDA things now. RT performance is more than good enough on RDNA4, no longer a generational difference, upscaler is a non-issue, and their drivers are actually better now funny enough. Trying to say 'you might as well buy the GeForce card' when the AMD card IS STILL CHEAPER, and offers the same performance and gaming features is nothing sort of foolish and definitely a 'shill' thing to say at this point.

Its a new world out there, your average gamer has TWO VALID OPTIONS NOW, and if your not in the high end, ARC Battlemage is even a valid THIRD option. Its no longer 'NVIDIA or your system is going to suck'. Saying 'you might as well buy the GeForce' simply because they have been around longer or have been the 'golden standard' is just simply a poor and incorrect statement, and REALLY sounds bad coming from a channel trying to be a reputable review outlet. ESPECIALLY given NVIDIA's recent attitude of ignoring their gamer customers and STILL not fixing everything that has gone wrong with Blackwell.
comments.author: @Jimmy-6300

comments.text:
So where AMD stands once again? (Even if we ignore current USA market which is the worst price ever and not even close to worth buying AMD cards at current prices) If we consider markets where prices are not as inflated as in USA, 9070 XT can be found for ~750€ and 5070 Ti can be found for ~840€, at those prices 9070 XT still provides ~8% better value in raster performance and ~3% better value in ray tracing. What was "promised" with MSRP was ~20% better value in raster and ~15% better value in ray tracing. So yes. AMD is back to the old ways, 10% cheaper and call it a day. 
Yes new FSR closed the gap significantly, but DLSS 4 is still better.
nVidia cards are still generally better supported in professional workloads 
nVidia (5070 Ti vs 9070 XT) consumes ~10% less power
All in all not impressed with any of them.

comments.text:
Not going to defend either party here, but hearing anyone say "Nvidia and their partners are doing a better job keeping cards closer to their MSRP" makes my head tilt in confusion. Show me where the 5080 and 5090 are anywhere remotely close to their MSRP, exactly? Might I remind you that Nvidia didn't have looming tariffs as an excuse for their hyper inflated prices, they just didn't supply anything to stores and did so to jack up prices for each card as much as possible.

AMD came out and launched in full force, selling for higher than MSRP, but offering performance and stability, for enough of an extended period that it cemented them as the defacto 'better buy' across the board.  Team red isn't free of faults in their own right, but I don't think they're in the same vein as where team green resides. AMD is at least supplying cards en-masse vs Nvidia, who might be doing the same thing NOW, three months post-launch, but it's too little too late as far as I can tell and demand for these GPUs is through the roof.

I spoke to one of the managers for the local best buy and he mentioned every shipment they get in for AMD and Nvidia vanishes almost immediately. They restock the night before, morning comes, by day's end they're sold out of everything. Their GPU cages have been completely devoid every time I've gone by there.

comments.text:
Yes or no answer. Do Nvidia's cards have superior features to AMD? 

AMD are still playing catch up to DLSS 4 and Nvidia's ray tracing performance even if FSR 4 is close (and mind you is only available on one generation of card while DLSS 4 works on every single RT capable Nvidia card, and while DLSS is in far more games than FSR and while DLSS 4 can override any DLSS 2 or 3 game, while FSR's override only works on FSR 3.1 games). AMD's technology still is not in as many games as Nvidia's. AMD's Anti Lag 2 is still in less than 10 games, then you compare that to Reflex. AMD's cards lag behind Nvidia in compute power, AMD's ROCm is still basically vapourware.  

 AMD cannot price their cards like Nvidia's because they are NOT Nvidia. There's a reason AMD had to pay retailers a rebate on the first batch of cards. AMD planned to sell the cards at a much higher price and changed their mind at the last minute because it would not sell relative to Nvidia and because AMD did not expect Nvidia's MSRP to be as low as it was.

comments.text:
The 9070XT was supposed to cost around 670€ in Germany. Remember that only American prices are allowed to not include sales tax in the advertised price. Every other country requires by law to advertise price with all sales tax, VAT or whatever included. That being said, I have been watching prices like a hawk and they are stuck at 750€ and it does not seem to matter if it is an OC model or not. I have decided to give the cards and the general upgrades a pass. And any game that does not run at 1440p at good visuals and consistent 60fps on my 6800XT has been relegated to the "buy at a Steam sale in 10 years or so" pile. In fact I am now playing a lot of games I bough for 3€ a pop on GOG on my Steamdeck. If it does not run on that, onto the "buy when it costs 5€" pile it goes.  Like, seriously, go to GOG, filter on controller support, filter out DLC, set price to 5€ max and look at what you can get. Never played Alan Wake? You can play that with gyro controls on a Steamdeck. 570€ gets you an OLED Steamdeck and a dozen games to play on it. And the gyro adds a lot to the controller controls. And the highly customizable controls and the very haptic touchpads add so much to the whole package. 570€ + Alan Wake + Metro Last Light and Metro 33 and  Doom 2016 and Wolfenstein 2 and Outlast and a lot of games you never heard of for a total price of 600 bucks. 
I am so done with game engines which force raytracing/pathtracing/other indistinguishable upsells with some upscalers and fake frames which require graphics cards that cost more than 700 bucks and pull more than 300 watts. Like, wake me when they sell something that works without trickery at a reasonable price and reasonable power consumption. Imma gonna buy an electric bicycle for the 5k€ I had set aside for a new computer and take my Steamdeck with me on nice bike trips over the summer.
comments.author: @bjorn-falkoandreas9472

I know some guys who sell wholesale of those parts. Ngreedia and AMD are just milking everyone and agreeing to do it, it's a classic duopoly but their fanboys keep protecting them so they just laugh in their boardrooms while milking everyone.

With some calculations take note that if you are buying in wholesale the parts will be CHEAPER since companies get a discount if they order in large quantities, that's just how wholesale works. The 9070 XT would just be around $300-400 USD based on parts price so you pay them an almost 100% profit margin.

The RTX 5090 calculating all the parts and the advanced gddr7 ram modules having 16x2gb memory modules at $25-30 each and rest of the other parts the 5090 would just cost around $700-800 to manufacture again more than +100% profit.

Take note majority of businesses in the world target around a 25-50% profit margin, of course milkers like these GPU companies and a other "premium" brands target +100% profit margin per product which is just greedy but their fanboys will just keep on protecting them while throwing away their money.

comments.text:
Ukrainian looking to upgrade this year. As of right now:
-cheapest 9070xt (XFX Swift) is 775.80$
-cheapest 5070ti (KFA2 EX GAMER-1) is 948.28$
Never heard of KFA2, card looks like shit, IMO. MSI Shadow is like 1c more expensive, I'd take that over the other one.
Neither is anywhere near MSRP, but they are within 30% markup, which for local retailers is actually not that bad on new tech. It was much worse a few months ago, around 60% markup. Took a long time for RTX4000 and RX7000 to go down to msrp, and then RTX shot up with release of 5000 lineup.
The first one to appear under 30% markup was ironically 5080 at 1250$, which for a while I considered, but ultimately decided the 20 more fps are not worth 500$ more, so it's out of my wishlist, and I instead redirected the allocated budget in favor of 9800x3d over 9700x. I'm way more likely to upgrade a GPU than CPU, so i'd rather overspend on CPU.
For now I'm set on 9070xt, we'll see if by the time I'm ready to pull the trigger on this I change my mind. If 5070ti suddenly drops to ~800$ while 9070xt remains where it is - that'd change my mind.

comments.text: The AU MSRP already takes into account the country's tariffs and non-tariff barriers. Entering the AU, means there is a $227 USD equivalent penalty (or a $351 AUD penalty tariff + non-tariff barrier). MSRP is the price that covers all expenses + achieves the desired profit margin for the company. All structural costs go into an MSRP.

comments.text:
This generation should be named, "The marketing wars". That's all this generation has been. Paper launches, extremely inflated prices, false promises, fake MSRP, false advertizing and the list goes on. But it all comes back to marketing and maneuvering. $600 wasn't what I was hoping it would MSRP for, but was willing to accept it. I personally believe AMD intended to sell it at $750 and chose at the last second to change it for optics. When they got their good press, the shouts from the rooftop that AMD was going to be the savior of PC gaming and the cheers went up, their strategy worked. Now that the dust has settled and the card is vastly more expensive than "intended", they are not continuing the rebates to allow MSRP sales. No one really knows what is going on behind the scenes right now, but I'm not seeing anything to indicate that they are doing anything other than riding the high. 

It's been said by many more times than can be counted, "Never underestimate AMD's ability to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory". No one is better at wasting an opportunity for success than AMD.

I can only speak from recent experience (last week) having bought a mid range 9070xt in the uk for £637 including shipping which is about £50 more than it would have been launch day had I been able to get one. No way I could get a 5070ti any less than about 750-800 and that wouldn't be mid range. Having got it, it is way more than expected and FSR4 isn't that far away from DLSS4 so pretty level playing field between the 2 now the world knows how good the 9070XT is.
That said, my card was on offer, now gone but the offer actually increased after I bought mine and within a day they'd all gone so whilst I could be disappointed paying a bit more, they're now gone and it wasn't a limited supply so what is a retailer to do?? .... and it is them that set the price. As for 5070 prices, they still can't sell them due to 12gb and performance somewhere between  the 4070 and 4070 super.
So, is the 9070xt worth what I paid? All day long it is! I appreciate this is UK not the rest of the world but it it's folly to expect that anything that disappears of the shelves as fast as the 9070xt does, is ever going to plummet in price. The intel cards are dropping because they aren't selling.

comments.text:
In reverse order:
Nvidia’s actually the one on better standing with their DLSS support, DLSS and Ray Reconstruction are available on all RTX GPUs, the only thing that’s been gatekept is frame generation that everyone says is worthless anyways. Whereas AMD is the one that’s obsoleted their FSR support with their next generation.

Missing ROPS are a hardware defect, and if you’re affected you are absolutely, positively entitled to a warranty replacement with one that isn’t affected. 

“Fake promises” I genuinely can’t remember what this is meant to refer to (outside maybe the ridiculous 5070=4090 claims?) but here’s some fake promises from AMD: “the MSRP” “FSR4 supported titles” “ROCm support” “7900XTX is 1.7x faster” and if we want to extend to CPUs, “Threadripper socket support”

Broken drivers: fair point, but AMD drivers have had plenty of flaws in the last few generations. 5700 black screens, and VAC bans come to mind. Both suck.

comments.text:
I'd take Mindfactory prices with a heavy grain of salt.    
The company barely avoided filing bankruptcy a couple of months ago and is currently restructuring under its own government (a form of 
insolvency legal in Germany if certain conditions are met).   
So while the company is still alive it does come with some sort of uncertainity and risks to the customers especially when it comes to available payment options and potential problems with customer support services.     
That whole situation was also the reason they didn't have any cards at launch whatsoever despite being one of the biggest retailers in that field in Germany.   
So while their prices are low (which caused the whole mess in the first place) and you will surely get the cards from them,  if there are any problems (returns, warrenty, etc.) with it you might be having a hard time.

comments.text:
Canadian here - Newegg is always heavily overpriced, a lot of their stock comes through America, as it's a US-based company. As a result, most of the people I know who build their own computers shop at Memory Express and Canada Computers. At ME, there are two 9070XTs below $1000 CAD (~$715 USD rn), 7 models between $1000-$1100 CAD (~$788 USD rn), and 4 models between $1100-$1250 CAD ($895 USD rn). The cheapest model at ME is $960 CAD, which is $687 USD. I'd have done a similar breakdown for CC, but their website sucks, and isn't loading this morning.

Both sites offer online orders and shipping to residential addresses, so it's not like it's an "only if you live near one!" thing. The only reason I order from Newegg is if I can't find it at one of the other stores, but half the time the price is out of whack because it's a third party seller anyways. Thanks, Bezos.

So anyways, while I agree that prices are inflated, Newegg.ca is an awful way to gauge how we're doing.

comments.text: You can only blame the chip manufacturer so much. Everyone in the supply chain wants his slice and the more hype there is, the bigger they want that slice to be. There's tariffs and other uncertainties to deal with, and the hyperinflation of the last 5 years is easily ignored in luxuries and impossible to miss in a grocery store, but there's also sheer flat oldfashioned greed, both from private scalpers trying to hustle and from major retailers. Times are tougher, so there's more hustlers and more greed. It wouldn't have been a problem if wages inflated as hard as currency supply did. Instead people's purchasing power has been castrated, and we're being asked to pay for that privilege so corporations avoid the same fate. I'm not against the prices or anything, I'm just not gonna pay them. That's not my problem, that's the corporations' problem. They can go deal with it if they want.

comments.text:
The takeaway is that fake MSRPs to get reviews is the marketing genius move of the decade. If the AMD card reviews bad, it won't sell with a 30% discount relative to Nvidia. If the AMD cards review good, they can sell at or above Nvidia. How the prices are supposed to be relative to each other doesn't matter.

You can't blame them for selling at what people will pay. Its a supply problem all around, you can see 9070 XTs going for around $720 USD and even the rare $650 USD, and they get snapped up in literally seconds. I managed to get mine at $720 but you have to be fast.

I think in the future the solution is that all card recommendations should ignore MSRP entirely and simply say "buy this if its at least x% cheaper than (insert closest competition) or only y% more expensive than (insert next tier up)"

I personally do not know the truth here but AMD might not be the only reason why prices are so high for their GPU's. 
Sure they should negotiate with manufacture brands about these things.
But to me the high prices scream more that the manufacture brands like MSI, AMD etc. and the whole pipeline is at fault here.
The gpu market has had inflated the prices over recent years so much that now it is the norm to keep the prices high. Certain models of these GPU's are ridiculously overpriced concidering how little they offer as "extra" to the more base models.
So. 
To bring the gpu prices down is to provide more supply which is difficult for AMD as they have been in a tough market position for a long time now. They just simply do not have enough production. 
This keeps prices high as there is still demand for AMD gpu's for the current prices. We will see prices going down when AMD gpu's do not sell anymore at the rate of new units being delivered to regional markets.

comments.text:
7:10 - No, it shouldn't, as that would have made it 538 without VAT. Aint no way AMD/NVIDIA are willing to sell their GPUs below their US MSRP. Look at the price of the 5070Ti on NVIDIA's official german site - "from" 879 euro. Minus VAT that makes it ~740 euro, which is in-line with US MSRP of $750. So for the 9070XTs 745 euro price, you deduct VAT and get ~625 euro price. Now yes, it's still above US MSRP, sligthly, but definitely not as bad as you make it out to be.

US MSRPs do not include any sales tax. European prices do include VAT, which is different in different countries. So you can't just compare US prices to EU prices WITH VAT and conclude that either NVIDIA or AMD are selling their GPUs way above MSRP. Actually they are quite close now in EU. Which is a bummer onto itself as usually you'd see prices go below MSRP few months after release but hey, that's the world we're living in 🤷‍♂

Over here, the 9070 starts around 700€, the 9070 XT starts around 850€, the 5070 starts around 650€, and the 5070 ti starts at over 1050€.

Right now, at least over here, the Radeon XT card would be (and has been) my pick, but if the Geforce cards come down in price, it would definitely change the value proposition. At the time of my purchase, the Geforce cards felt prohibitively expensive, while the Radeons felt "only" expensive. Still, this is definitely an "only buy a new GPU if you absolutely must" market. Demand goes up, prices go crazy... We've seen that in recent years(mining boom, covid shortage) . I don't buy the whole panic mode. If demand is back down and supply is good the sales will come. I mean, if you have money and need a gpu go for it. It's fun, you earned it! But buying overspending in these low stock uncertain situations is never worth it. The companies use people's fomo to push prices up, that's all that's happening.

comments.text:
If you believe what microeconomics says, even though supply/demand still have an effect, a monopoly/duopoly situation will always lower consumer surplus to the benefit of the producer. So the price will always be higher than it should be until more competitors enter the market. 

You've also got the issue that leading edge nodes are only fabbed by two companies (TSMC and Samsung) with HUGE demand from big players including apple, qualcomm, etc., meaning that they can effectively name their price. Plus fab space for niche products like gaming GPUs is extremely limited, particularly now that every single techbro in silicon valley is trying to push AI into everything.

Our best bet for GPU competition is Intel. I hope to god they don't pull out of the GPU arms race because they're just about the only ones who have the ability to meaningfully compete with nvidia and amd.

Obviously it's a bit more nuanced than just that (you've got price elasticity of demand which was proven to be extremely low during the covid crisis which gave the all ahead for AMD/nvidia to keep prices high even after supply shocks subsided, nvidia's extremely effective (and questionable) marketing tactics, etc etc) but that's the broad strokes.

comments.text:
Reviewers : "The 9070 xt is a great card with an amazing value proposition at $600" 
Buyers: "He said the 9070 xt is the best card money can buy" 

hence why it's going out of stock everywhere and maintaining it's price.

Jokes aside I wouldn't be surprised if some sellers started to price match cards based on performance rather than MSRP. That's kind of what happens in Argentina.
Both the 5070 and the 9070 are selling for about U$870.
The 5070 TI is selling for U$1175.
The 9070 XT is selling for U$1086.

The reason for those ludicrously high prices in a country where the median income is around U$400 is because afaik, sellers here have almost always prefered maintining stock than lowering prices to boost sales, because of the economic instability and high inflation rates. That's going away for the most part, but if cards are still selling with close to a 100% profit margin, I don't see store owners lowering prices any time soon. Too much time stuck in that mindset (selling high/maintaining stock to cushion for inflation) and stores  are not competing, they're colluding and maintining prices high regardless of the steadily declining inflation rates, and removal of taxes and tarifs. Their margins only going further up and stock always high.

Best example of what I mentined above was back in april when the gobernment removed the limit on USD currency exchange and the exchange rate went DOWN meaning the same amount of ARS would get you more USD, but prices of things still went UP. Which makes no sense, but that's Argentina in a nutshell. No matter what happens, prices always go UP.

comments.text:
A lot of people are not going to like this take but I genuinely don't think it's AMD's fault and here's why :
- first of all, have you seen the world's economies right now ? would not be surprised at all if there was a lot of that price increase caused by how unstable markets are due to expectations of tariffs or something (even when it's not the actual fault of tariffs, directly or indirectly)
- my primary theory is that retailers saw the prices scalpers were reselling GPUs at and figured they might as well be the ones pocketing the money instead, retailer launch prices I've seen on Day Zero were already stupid, which could explain why this series wasn't a scalped as it would have
- secondary theory is AMD & partners were planning on a 650-750 MSRP launch, so they made a bill of materials to put on PCBs accordingly I guess ? TSMC was selling their wafers for quite a lot as well and they're AMD's exclusive supplier (since they work too closely with AMD for AMD to consider getting wafers somewhere else) so I'm guessing AMD cancelled their OEM models because they were going to be sold at a loss otherwise and partners were told to eat the cost for a while and some just didn't care so they priced it as it would originally be ? (XFX ?)
- I had a third point but I forgot lmao
This is all a lot of guess work on my end but I think I'm right about most of it or that at least they're valid ideas about why that mess is like this :P

comments.text:
Well they have too! The USD is weak, and unlike the rest of the world where people have the luxury to complain about the pricing.... we literally don't even have much GPU (or CPU) stock here in the states to complain about. So people with money are paying $800 - $4,500 for GPUs, because that's mostly all we have to buy reliably. Sure there will be stock in one week for closer to MSRP, and then its all gone for the rest of the month or two. 

Reading comments from people on here in Europe and Asian complaining about 700 and 800 Euro MSRP's is actually funny to me, considering the same cards are rarely in stock here and can go for 25% more on a good day and 50% more on a bad day when Tariff talk causes panic buying and reseller gouging. If you go to online retailers it's just mostly empty stock, and some terribly over-priced stock online that will not move. Right now is actually an exception to the rule, and a great time to have made this video as there hasn't been much stock on Newegg for literally months... until the start of this month when they got stock - which wont last long (and then we are back to were we where again). 

Right now even the prebuilt are almost all sold out (unless you want junk) and super inflated. And the oasis which is Micro Center (one of the few places to get a GPU and for MSRP) is exceptionally regional (90% of Americans don't have one near them) and they don't sell much of their GPU stuff online (only in store). Leaving most to deal with the hostile Newegg or Amazon desert. So Hardware Unboxed has to focus on the rest of the world were people can actually BUY a GPU, and PC hardware (for as expensive as it is) isn't radically inflating in price over night day-to-day like it is here in the States. Not just GPUs, but CPUs, motherboards and the entire hardware scene here in the US is unstable, volatile and feels like a war-zone then famine then warzone then famine.

We are in a new era where the US is gonna be left behind. I guess all these Youtube Channels and business have to prioritize the rest of the world finally, and go where the prosperity/opportunity is as we shot ourself in both feet.

@SurviveOnlyStrong  Why does a single person matter? I think the statistics are more useful. The minimum salary after tax is ~1100€, which (or close to it) 15% to 20% of people in Spain get. The median (average man) salary is 1500€.
Cost of living, for single person, is around 700 without rent, and with rent around 1500.
To have spare money left for hobbies like buying videocards you either have to live with someone like friends or stay with family, or have an above average paying job.
There's also variability by region/city. Barcelona is around 25% more expensive than Malaga to live in, in my humble estimation lol, but also has slightly higher wages, for example.

comments.text:
Was a bit to be expected.

NVidia f'd up massively this gen, and many customers flocked to AMD. Despite having been shelved for a couple months giving them great stock at launch, it sold like hotcakes and was out of stock very quickly. All AMD could do from the reaction was to ask TSMC to get a higher wafer allocation so they could get more chips made, but until those increased production cards arrive will still take a bit of time (I expect mid-June for the stock and with it the prices to start easing somewhat) for it to affect pricing. 

NVidia's prices are so low because they're unpopular and sit on shelves much longer than NVidia cards are used to, and AMD's cards are so expensive because they sell out pretty much as soon as they get in stock. e-tailer Alternate for instance has at the time of writing no 9070 and only one white 9070XT model in stock, while the 5060Ti and 5070 taken together have over 50 models in stock, many of them at or below MSRP. And the higher-tier models also have been consistently in stock now and their prices slipping further and further, with the 5080 also available below MSRP now.

I get why this video is being made and I agree with the sentiment - but I think it has been made too early. By July the stock should be better, and then we can look if it's just due to shortages or if the prices stay high. I saw the prices of the 9070/XT drop slowly over at Alternate over the last couple weeks (when cards got in stock), suggesting it's due to stock issues (NVidia, who don't really have stock issues anymore, dropped also, but much faster than AMD's prices). Until then, I think we should withhold judgement.

As for AMD not wanting to sell the cards at that price, I dunno. It may very well be that AMD wanted a higher price but was afraid to get called "NVidia -$50" again and took a deeper cut because of that. But considering that many other cards did it the other way around (slightly undercutting NVidia's price, getting called out for it and then almost immediately dropping the price afterwards), I do believe that the price of 9070 is more or less where AMD wanted it anyway (9070XT was probably aimed higher originally), and pricing sometimes reflect that. The cheapest 9070 if found on Alternate over the last 2 weeks was 636€, which is just a hair over the 629€ MSRP. But it also sounds that no matter how they do it they'll get called out on their prices.

comments.text: This is the way I see it. 1) the lead time for going from blank silicon wafer to etched wafer is about 4 months. that doesn't count packaging and then mounting on a graphics board . 2) Amd was at about 15% of the market ( lower at the high end of graphic cards ) Say they assumed a great increase in sales. say an increase of 20% of what they have . that is a big gamble .you are laying out a lot of money to assume that much of a gain. that would mean they would expect grow to 18% of the market. ( 15% + (20% of 15%) ) . If they are wrong there is too much stock and loose money. So if you were AMD would you have increased production before the launch? Now the flip side is the reverse for Nvidia. Nvidia has 85% of the market and there lose of market share is less than 2% of their current market.. that adds some stock in the works, but nothing that can not be absorb by shelf space. I assumed AMD allocated more production at tsmc the day of launch, but those chips are only 1/2 way through their 4 month production cycle. BTW 14 nm wafer is 60 days, so as die shrink, lead time increases.So yes this would have been solved by now in the rx580 days .given all that is going on, I think your summation did not include these factors.

comments.text:
AMD have started to be called out over their pricing of the 9070/9070XT on a number of channels. I'm glad Tim has taken the time to highlight the difference in many markets showing this discrepancy between advertised and real. I have to agree with the hypothesis of AMD never wanting to sell this card for a lower price. However I am worried for the next gen of cards, which are being hyped up already. It seems that with nVidia now charging whatever it wants, that AMD will just follow suite and prioritise shareholder returns over developing a competitive market.
This is the kind of short term thinking that will kill the goose that laid the golden egg. i.e. Price out gamers that buy GPUs and cripple the gaming industry making it a smaller market.
comments.author: @igavinwood

comments.text:
The prices are whatever the market is willing to pay, coupled with other factors:  Nvidia sold above MSRP when they had no competition which isn't the case anymore, and they technically arrived late to the market. Then there was FSR4 which all but nullified the huge advantage DLSS had in the past.  

Add to that, issues with poor drivers and the surprisingly competitive 9070 XT matching or besting the competition. 

 IMO, all of those factors have contributed to the prices we're seeing now. If the 9070 XT wasn't as sought after as it was, the AIBs would be forced to lower their prices given the flood of Nvidia cards.

comments.text:
AMD definitely followed Nvidia’s fake MSRP approach this gen, but the real reason everyone is buying them sustaining these inflated launch prices is revulsion with Nvidia’s games finally making a lot of gamers jump ship…even after Nvidia finally decided to make supply available leading to debatably better pricing at times, of all things.

Let’s be real…Nvidia still has more market share. AMD hasn’t had to contract TSMC to have GPUs manufactured at Nvidia’s scale of recent years at any point in their history. It’s still a smaller percentage of the market that is buying them…but AMD’s still-smaller production volume is what’s actually holding their prices up.

I do think we’re finally approaching when that will change. On Newegg I’ve noticed one model of non-XT 9070 sometimes remaining in stock at $650USD for sometimes days at a time. One model of 9070XT in a combo deal with a 27” monitor has stayed in stock a few days at $825. The monitor alone sells for $135, so the GPU is effectively $690.

Most models of 9070XTs are now finally remaining in stock most of the time. Now they need to get to the point where they’re sitting on shelves. AMD wants market share. Their AIBs had better be on the same page if they know what’s good for them. They’ll need to inch prices down to where they were initially intending if they want to sustain sales. That may never be the $600MSRP, but it also isn’t anywhere near the $900+ that’s still typical on the market.

A titanic confounder in the US however is Trump’s ongoing tariff theatrics. It appears Nvidia is already going ahead and using it as an excuse to permanently increase their MSRPs, even while Trump will likely fold as his voters start realizing tariffs ultimately are taxes on them as consumers. Microsoft has already done the same with their Series Xbox models, which use AMD APUs. It seems no matter what ultimately plays out in the political arena, the door was already opened and corporations will use the excuse to permanently increase prices on US consumers even if the tariffs never happen.

Point blank, it would be naive to not expect AMD to do the same. The real question is whether or not the magnitude overshadows the current initial price inflation. My guess is not quite. I do think these prices are at least a bit more likely than not to normalize a bit more at least over the next several months (I can’t even guess what develops in such a needlessly dramatic political environment beyond that, nor what economic fallout we may be in for).

AMD wants marketshare. They want mindshare. They were at 10% marketshare a few months ago and had better realize they don’t want to find themselves in that situation again. Especially with Intel planning to employ 3D V-cache and Nvidia also looking to jump into the CPU space. AMD’s current dominance with Ryzen could evaporate in very little time, and AI may remain their best bet to stay in a good position. They have to remain competitive in graphics cards. They better realize they can’t afford to sit pat.

comments.text:
I guesss, in order to understand, how much (and how awfully) we screw(ed) ourselves via keep feeding the gpu designer companies, we need lay down some facts on the table and examine them individually.
So... Lets assume (for the argument's sake) we have some rtx 5000 card currently and we reached to that point by spending (additional) 300 $ on each new generation and trade old graphics card we had.
Therefore, lets get highly moderate and assume that we have spent 329 $ for GTX 970 back in 2014
Obviously, it will give us the waaaay under the average pc user's graphics card expenditure. Because, in reality, we have spent significantly more.
But lets do it anyway, just to see how much we hurt ourselves financially even the figures are way less than the reality we are in.

February 2025 - RTX 5000 generation - 300 $ Upgrade cost
October 2022 - RTX 4000 generation - 300 $ Upgrade cost
September 2020 - RTX 3000 generation - 300 $ Upgrade cost
September 2018 - RTX 2000 generation - 300 $ Upgrade cost
May 2016 - RTX 1000 generation - 300 $ Upgrade cost
September 2014 - GTX 900 generation - 329 $ GTX 970 cost
-------------------------------------------------
Total 1829 $ spent along the way and we just can not exactly know which graphics card we may have end up with. rtx 5060ti or rtx 5070? Who knows?
But the point is, for any average user who upgraded every gen, total expenditure is waaaay above 2000 $ (unfortunately)

So... Lets have a look at the alternative road maps, instead of blindly financing gpu designer companies and their aib partners;

Alternative option a:
We may invest to our own financial wellbeings via precious metals.

September 2014 - We may acquire 329 $ worth of gold when it's ons was 1230 $ (which makes = 0,267 ons)
May 2016 - We may get more 300 $ worth of gold when it's ons was - 1260 $ (which makes = 0,238 ons)
September 2018 - We may get more 300 $ worth of gold when it's ons was - 1200 $ (which makes = 0,25 ons)
September 2020 - We may get more 300 $ worth of gold when it's ons was - 1900 $ (which makes = 0,157 ons)
October 2022 - We may get more 300 $ worth of gold when it's ons was - 1650 $ (which makes = 0,181 ons)
February 2025 - We may get more 300 $ worth of gold when it's ons was - 2800 $ (which makes = 0,107 ons)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total of 1,2 ons of gold, which is roughly worth of  3890 $ on 13.05.2025 and likely to more in the future.

No need to mention that, 1,2 ons of gold is worth more than double the 1829 $ which we (blindly) gave away to gpu designer companies.
If $ continue to lose it's purchasing power, obviously the 1,2 ons of golf we have, will be able able to purchase more products and services in mid and long-term future.

Lets have look at the another possible alternative option (b):

September 2014 - We may acquire 329 $ worth of bitcoin when it was 394 $ (0,835 bitcoin)
May 2016 - We may get more 300 $ worth of bitcoin when it was 473 $ (0,634 bitcoin)
September 2018 - We may get more 300 $ worth of bitcoin when it was 6735 $ (0,044 bitcoin)
September 2020 - We may get more 300 $ worth of bitcoin when it was 10948 $ (0,027 bitcoin)
October 2022 - We may get more 300 $ worth of bitcoin when it was 20160 $ (0,014 bitcoin)
February 2025 - We may get more 300 $ worth of bitcoin when it was 97600 $ (0,003 bitcoin)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total of 1,5174 bitcoin which is roughly worth of 157236 $ on 13.05.2025

Again!
There is no need to mention that, 1,5174 bitcoin will worth more on both $ and (more importantly) purchasing power terms.

At some stage, we need to wake up and stop screwing ourselves via diretly feeding the "nvidia/amd/intel" trioploy and their aib partners.

From 2017-2018 onwards they openly started fixing prices against us all and stopped competing.
They keep set up artificial shortage scam and milk us all, full throttle.
It is also the blame of (both) current and many past govenments, as they prevent antitrust laws to be uphold to gpu designer companies.
They eat us all, like a open buffet since 2018...

comments.text: Your closing thoughts about how much AMD were caught out by Nvidia's launch pricing (even if team green have taken forever to get near MSRP) are spot on, I think. I worry that AMD aren't making much profit on these cards, because of Nvidia's prices. I worry AMD's shareholders' appetite to absorb losses on a generation that was meant to be playing it safe(!), and what that could mean for the future prospects for a decent discrete GPU from AMD. Having to rebate your partners so they can sell close to MSRP on launch is an awful own-goal from a business perspective, especially with Nvidia's woeful launch. And being able to sit there and laugh at Nvidia's woes is scant comfort when every card you're selling is costing you money. So if I was an AMD investor - why would I want the company to continue to pursue a losing market, when I see all the money the server and console/handheld markets are making?

This is quite simply a market reaction to supply and demand. The demand is what has driven this because the 9070xt has been selling much better than the NVidia counterparts. Some report state 10x the amount. So when the sales hit that kind of level it will inflate the price.

I'm not a fan of this kind of thing happening as I think price inflation ends up pricing out certain people unnecessarily... for instance a $600 GPU budget now has to be spent on a lower SKU resulting in less money for the seller. comments.text: lol, if you think 15% of people buying GPUs are paying more than $700, your smoking some strong stuff. If you excluded small businesses and power users making money off their GPU, it's probably closer to %4 or %5 of people who own gaming computers (which is still millions of people). BY FAR the most common GPUs sold in prior generations were cards under $300 (like the GTX 2060 and 1660, 3060 and 4060), and many people game on APUs. The typical hardcore pc gamer even isn't rocking a GPU over $700, even in this environment - the bulk of the 'pcmr' audience typically settles somewhere in the mid-range market. Barring current circumstances, $700 is where the High-End has begun (not the Halo tier) in the last several years and very few people can afford that.... which is why this generation is facing so much resistance and ire for the MSRP of the xx60 and xx70 series Nvidia cards. I typically buy High-End or Halo tier each generation, and when I see the steam surveys or read the steam comments/threads for new release - it humbles you, what even hardcore pc gamers are generally making due with.

comments.text: AMD might sell the chips at for example $250 per chip and take a 10% margin. Then OEMs produce a final product, boxed and all, and sell it for $400 taking a 10% margin. The next step in the chain, retailers, buy this for $400, pay shipping and temporary warehousing, add their own 25% margin (because it's not commercially interesting to stock otherwise) and sell it to the customer for $500. But wait, the customer buys the card for $500 and sells it on eBay for $800, taking a 30% margin. The retailer predicts and anticipates that move, and the next batch gets listed at $750 to undercut eBay hustlers. But wait, OEMs see this too, and raise price to $500 to get more out of the retailer. Maybe AMD reacts too, they'd be fools not to. It's a race to the top. People were warned not to buy scalped cards because this would happen, and now it has.
comments.author: @michelvanbriemen3459

comments.text:
@hircine92h  That is because they are too focused on short term per item margins rather than investing in market share. If you look at the net operating margins for these companies, the ones that were able to fully pull off anchoring a new higher pricing scheme (Nvidia), effectively increased their margins from from 14% at the time of the GTX 1000 cards (GTX 1070 MSRP was $379 at the time), to over 75% in 2025. The gouging pissed off a lot of people, and AMD failed to capitalize on it, and instead did a formula of Nvidia's minus 50 dollars. This ultimately made people think, the AMD card is slightly cheaper for similar raster performance, but with Nvidia I can pay $50 more and get DLSS, faster RT, NVENC, and a longer driver support cycle.

AMD chose to copy Nvidia's greed rather than taking their market share away. AMD could have kept the price change trends from 2002-2015, which would have effectively lead them to being around 50% cheaper than Nvidia by the time their RTX3000 series cards came out, and if Nvidia was unable to properly temper their greed, then AMD would have taken the majority of the market share.

comments.text:
What people have forgotten is that MSRP, RRP, whatever it's called, is supposed to be unique to each retail market and account for taxes, tarriffs, and shipping costs.

What companies have been actually doing is state the MSRP of whatever market had the lowest taxes and tariffs. For decades that has been the US market, which is why the cost of things always seemed so much worse for Australia, which has much higher costs to ship products to, and the EU, which has the VAT.

Now, the USA suddenly has the highest tarriffs, surprising the companies as they launched products, and I expect we'll see that reflected in the next series of GPUs.
comments.author: @TheZoenGaming

comments.text: You realize PC parts were always excluded from Tarrifs right.
comments.author: @TopShot501st

comments.text: @TopShot501st  Considering that there's been 5% tarriff in the USA that applied to all Chinese products and anything that said, "Made in China", since 2015, I'd have to disagree.
comments.author: @TheZoenGaming

comments.text: @TheZoenGaming  refer to the actual trade code then,  HTSUS code 8473.30
comments.author: @TopShot501st

comments.text: Well msrp is basically just a recommended selling price for the consumer. The manufacturer can recommend this and that, doesnt mean retailers sell it or has to sell it at that price. So really i would focus more on retailers here. Retailers for sure dont want to cut any of their profit margins, if anything raise them to absolute maximums. How big of a profit margin do retailers have that sell these consumer gpus for example. I would guess a massive one. But those are business secrets of course. And consumers tend to let retailers off the hook.
comments.author: @manefin

comments.text:
@manefin  Retailers know that excessively high prices will cause a market to collapse due to a lack of sales, so they generally follow MSRP. The only reason that hasn't happened with the GPU market is due to a number of cryptocurrency booms and the AI boom. 

Also, your lack of knowledge about economic laws is frightening. The USA has several laws regarding the price at which retailers can sell goods, how the goods can be advertised, and even the volume of goods. The only products that don't have a cap are things that are being resold by an individual, are considered collectible, are very old, or are very rare. That's why the FTC has stopped predatory pricing and advertising practices in the past.

Even after the new higher VRAM model comes out, the $999 FE model is the one that lose the least amount of resale value. Everything is pointing higher prices for new models, and the GDDR7 is still expensive. The new model will most likely cost at least $1200 or higher. The new FE model will be hard to buy and other models are going to cost even more.

While AMD’s official launch MSRP for the RX 9070 XT is $599, and the Taichi OC variant is listed at $730 internationally, actual retail prices are significantly higher in many regions-including India-due to limited supply and high demand. The notion of MSRP has become largely theoretical for both AMD and Nvidia, as most cards are sold well above these reference prices, making the MSRP more of a marketing anchor than a real-world expectation.

comments.text:
​ @b-rant  The 4060 is actually closer to 3x faster than the 1060, and it's $300 MSRP is about 10% less than the 1060 MSRP adjusted for inflation. This is as expected though, because it should cost less money to get the same performance over time as technology improves.

The issue is the rate at which price/performance is improving. The value increase going from 960-1060-2060 was huge each time, but the value increase from 2060-3060-4060 has been MUCH smaller. The 5060 is looking like it'll be the worst value uptick yet (value may actually decrease).

I understand it's getting more difficult to find ways to improve performance, but if performance improvements are slowing down then prices should decrease to maintain that steadily increasing price/performance line. Instead, prices are increasing because companies want to keep their profit margins even though they're not providing the performance improvements customers have come to expect.

comments.text:
Yes, this is the problem with this GPU. It's a good product, but it was marketed as a "value" card. But to be value, it needs to be cheaper than the alternative. Same with the 9070 VS 5070. The Nvidia card is still cheaper than the AMD card.

AMD needs to be more aggressive with pricing if they want to get back marketshare. Once you lose the customers, it's not enough to just launch a good product if you want to win them back.
comments.author: @Tom_Quixote

comments.text: More aggressive pricing would only reduce availability and it feeds scalping because of scarcity. It doesn't have any real impact on market share because the supply is not magically increasing in short term. Even if TSMC had unused capacity(which they don't), it would take minimum 6 months to get this extra production actually on the shelves. Cannibalizing other AMD chips for wafers is not a solution either. Whatever wafer allocation AMD decided to do in 2024, that's the limit of the supply for most of the this year.
comments.author: @kognak6640

comments.text:
@kognak6640  Prices follow supply and demand. I'm talking about the way these cards were marketed. They knew supply would be limited, but still told a story about a cheap card that they must have known would not be possible.

If AMD had produced and sold all their cards directly to consumers instead of through middlemen (board partners), they could have set the price as they wanted. Demand would still be high, but the cards would be coveted and people could sign up for a waiting list to buy one. There would still be scalpers and second-hand sales, but the narrative would be much better for AMD than coming out with a deceptive MSRP.
comments.author: @Tom_Quixote

comments.text:
@Tom_Quixote  Why would AMD ever do that? Not having their own distributing channels, it would be costly to create ones worldwide. AMD store is just a relatively small 3rd party contractor, they would never be able to ship in volume covering whole continent. Board partners exists for a reason.
And for the MSRP, it's obvious why AMD did that. Getting positive reviews is everything, doesn't matter what real prices are. The first impressions simply sticks. For example right now 9070 is better buy in value than XT but people prefer strongly XT because reviews said non-XT is worse buy than XT based on MSRP. Case of 7900XT is even better, it never really recovered from bad reviews despite big price cuts. AMD definitely should use fake MSRP in the future, getting flak from it is minuscule compared other way around. Nvidia's reputation is far more robust, bad reviews hurt but cards won't turn into radioactive waste, they still sell ok.
comments.author: @kognak6640

comments.text: @kognak6640  I understand why both companies are deliberately misleading people with too low MSRPs. But when AMD is trying to play catch up, they can't just keep doing the same thing. They need to change their business strategy. Producing more of the cards themselves (through a partner if need be) and selling them at a lower margin would be a way to regain market share. Especially at a time where dissatisfaction with Nvidia is at an all-time high, it would have been an easy reputational win.
comments.author: @Tom_Quixote

The msrp of a gpu is largely irrelevant. The products actual price changes even between two neighbouring countries. And also the price of the product changes a lot in rather short time. And availability of the product in the first place changes massively too. 

So its more like msrp can be taken something like "the price of x product can be as low as this figure maybe. But maybe not. Who knows". And thats all it is useful for so not for much. But i at least wont be paying and lining up and waiting for a 900 or plus euros gpu so i can play a video game thats for sure.
